abstract.t: This document specifies the URI (Uniform Resource Identifier) scheme "about". About URIs are designed to be an internal, application-level identifier. Unlike many other URI schemes, the resolution of, and resources represented by, about URIs are left entirely to each individual application.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: An about URI is designed to be used internally by applications for almost any desired purpose. Such URIs have commonly been used by web browsers for proving access to built-in functionality, such as application preferences and settings, information about the application, or "easter eggs".

About URIs are more memorable than an equivalent urn or tag URI. Using an http URI would not only be less memorable, but also longer and semantically confusing. While any number of existing schemes could be used to identify such resources, about URIs have become the de facto standard. Browsers already use the about scheme. The about:blank URI is ubiquitous, and some browsers also provide other resources with the about scheme, including those in .It may be reasonable to also define an about URN scheme and define about URIs as a provisional shorthand for those URNs.

section.title: Resolving About URIs
section.t: In general, applications are free to resolve any about URI to any resource, either internal or external, or redirect to an alternative URI, with being the only exception.

As about URIs are designed to be internal to each application, there is no expectation of any URI, except , returning the same resource among different applications. However, it is worth noting that some conventions have arisen for providing particular functionality via common about URIs.

section.title: about:blank
section.t: This URI identifies an empty resource. If the application may use a document of MIME type 'text/html' and character encoding 'UTF-8', about:blank SHOULD be represented with an empty document. Other representations are not defined.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: There is no guarantee that an application will understand any about URI provided to it. An about URI may not resolve to the expected resource. If the reference is unlikely to resolve correctly, the reference should be accompanied by an explanation or alternatives.

Some applications are known to display arbitrary HTML following the scheme.see application program in RFC4949 Applications should be cautious when accessing an about URI. An application should not execute or display information in an about URI.see active content in RFC4949 About URIs should not cause the application to modify any data. Applications should not use about URIs to access, or erase files or other sensitive information.
